Legal_Issue: Whether 'CRÉMANT DE GLACE' is deceptively misdescriptive under paragraph 12(1)(b) of the Trade-marks Act
Procedural_Stage: Appeal from Trade-marks Opposition Board decision to Federal Court
Evidence_Assessment: Dictionary definitions of 'crémant' associated with wine; lack of evidence linking term to cider; public perception of sparkling wine from frozen fruit
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant (Verger du Minot Inc.) to demonstrate registrability
Credibility_Factor: Appellant's argument of whimsical interpretation not accepted by Board or Court
Legal_Rule: A trademark is deceptively misdescriptive if it misleads the public about the character or quality of the goods
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness standard applied in judicial review
Procedural_Issue: Consideration of additional evidence on appeal
Grounds_for_Claim: Opposition based on deceptive misdescription of goods
Decision_Maker: Trade-marks Opposition Board; affirmed by Federal Court
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Process deemed fair with opportunity to present evidence
Key_Evidence_Considered: Dictionary definitions, nature of product (apple cider vs. wine), consumer expectations
Legal_Framework: Canadian Trade-marks Act and case law on deceptive misdescription
Applicant_Challenge: Registration of 'CRÉMANT DE GLACE' for apple cider
Defendant_Response: Clos Saint-Denis Inc. opposed registration on grounds of deception
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, dictionary definitions, product descriptions
Remedy_Requested: Prevention of registration of the trademark
Resolution_Mechanism: Administrative opposition followed by judicial appeal
Claimant_Status: Appellant: Verger du Minot Inc.; Respondent: Clos Saint-Denis Inc.
Governing_Rule: Paragraph 12(1)(b) of the Trade-marks Act regarding deceptively misdescriptive marks
